title: Students want Gandhi statue scrapped in Manchester ‘because he’s racist’
text:
This planned 9ft statue of Mahatma Gandhi in Manchester has sparked protests (Picture: Shrimad Rajchandra Mission Dharampur/Getty)

Students in Manchester have called for a planned 9ft statue of Mahatma Gandhi to be scrapped because they claim he’s an ‘anti-black racist’.

Gandhi is revered worldwide for leading a peaceful campaign to end the rule of the British Empire in his homeland.

The Indian lawyer was assassinated aged 78 in 1948 a year after his country gained independence.

He was nominated for the Nobel peace prize five times.

Gandhi has, however, been criticised for his comments about African natives during the early 20th century Boer war between the British Empire troops and two states in what is now South Africa.

In response to the Manchester Arena bombing which killed 22 people in May 2017, an Indian spiritual mission called Shrimad Rajchandra Mission Dharampur has donated the Gandhi statue to the city.

Manchester Uni students are protesting against a planned statue in the city of Mahatma Gandh (Picture: Getty Images)

How the planned 9ft statue of Gandhi will look in Manchester city centre (Picture: Shrimad Rajchandra Mission Dharampur)

It is due to be unveiled outside Manchester Cathedral next month.

A global Gandhi Must Fall campaign which aims to remove monuments to the Indian pacifist is now being supported in Manchester.

Some Manchester Uni students, including student union liberation and access officer Sarah Khan, want to prevent the statue from being installed.

An open letter from the students read they ‘demand that Manchester City Council reconsider this decision on the basis of Gandhi’s well-documented anti-black racism and complicity in the British Empire’s actions in Africa.

‘Gandhi referred to Africans as “savages”, “half-heathen Natives”, “uncivilised”, “dirty” and “like animals”, to reference only a few of his comments.

Some students from the University of Manchester are protesting against the planned statue (Picture: Getty)

‘He saw himself as a “fellow-colonist”, theorising Indians as a superior race.

‘Gandhi was a virulent anti-black racist.

‘This statue would not promote peace but instead promote Gandhi’s racist and anti-black ideology, and promote continued violence in Kashmir.’

Gandhi lived in South Africa between 1893 and 1914.

In his later years he pioneered peaceful protests such as strikes, boycotts and vigils.

Professor Vinita Damodaran, Indian history expert of Sussex University, told Mail Online: ‘This campaign focuses on Gandhi’s views when he lived in South Africa and ignores everything else.

‘He moved on to become a very much more humane, much more inclusive person in his later years and he redacted these views.’

A Manchester City Council spokesman said: ‘Although we aware that there is some debate about Gandhi’s life, most people in the city will see the statue in the context in which it was intended – to spread a message of peace, love and harmony.’

description: The protest surrounds comments Gandhi made about African natives during the Boer War.
